column1: Tilburg (Dutch: [ˈtɪlbʏr(ə)x] (listen)) is a city in the Netherlands
column2: in the southern province of North Brabant. With a population of 217
column4: it is the second-largest municipality in North Brabant
column5: and the sixth largest in the Netherlands.

column1: Tilburg University is located in Tilburg
column2: as are Avans University of Applied Sciences and Fontys University of Applied Sciences.

column1: Tilburg is known for its ten-day-long funfair
column2: held in July each year. The Monday during the funfair is called "Roze Maandag" (Pink Monday)
column3: and is primarily LGBT-oriented.

column1: There are three railway stations within the municipality: Tilburg
column2: Tilburg Universiteit and Tilburg Reeshof. The 75-hectare (185-acre) "Spoorzone" area around Tilburg Central station
column3: once a Dutch Railways train maintenance yard
column4: has been purchased by the city and is being transformed into an urban zone.

column1: Little is known about the beginnings of Tilburg. The name Tilliburg first appeared in documents dating from AD 709
column2: but after that there was no mention for several centuries. In the later Middle Ages
column3: Tilburg referred to a region rather than a particular town or village; its population was largely in a couple of hamlets
column4: one of which was known as "Eastern Tilburg" (Oost-Tilburg)
column5: which was later reflected in the name Oisterwijk ("Eastern Quarter"). This village centred around a small (probably wooden) castle or Motteburcht on an equally small hill
column6: which became derelict and was torn down after a few centuries at most. Of this first "Tilburg Castle"
column7: nothing remained c. 2000
column8: except for a few remnants of its moat in the suburbs of Oisterwijk. In the 14th century
column9: Tilburg was proclaimed a manor; together with Goirle
column10: it acquired the title of "The Manor of Tilburg and Goirle".

column2: the manorial rights fell into the hands of several lords of noble lineage. They derived their income from taxes
column3: fines and interest paid by the villagers.

column2: one of the lords of Tilburg
column3: Jan van Haestrecht
column4: built Tilburg Castle. "That stone chamber at Hasselt" is mentioned in several historical documents. In 1858
column5: however
column6: the castle was pulled down to make way for a factory
column7: but the name lives on
column8: in the city arms and logo. A replica of the foundations of the castle was restored in ca. 1995 in its original location
column9: after the factory was demolished. In 1803
column10: Goirle was separated from Tilburg and on 18 April 1809
column11: Tilburg was granted city status. In that year
column13: 000 inhabitants. In 2009 Tilburg hosted several festivities in celebration of 200 years as a city.

column1: Tilburg grew around one of the so-called "herd places" or "Frankish triangles"
column2: triangular plots where a number of roads (usually sand roads) met. These herd places were collective pasturelands for flocks of sheep. Their shape is still reflected in the layout of many places in Tilburg. Many districts
column3: including Korvel
column4: Oerle
column5: Broekhoven
column6: Hasselt
column7: Heikant
column10: bear the names of these old hamlets. The poor farmers living in these hamlets soon decided not to sell the wool from their sheep but to weave it themselves
column12: much of the space inside their small houses was occupied by a loom—by the 17th century these numbered about 300. Enterprising people saw their chance. As so-called "drapers" they supplied the weavers with the raw materials for their "home working"
column13: and the first Tilburg "mill houses" came into existence. From then on
column14: the wool industry underwent rapid growth
column15: and in 1881 Tilburg had as many as 145 wool mills. Home weaving continued
column17: until the early 20th century. Woollen textiles from Tilburg were known far and wide. After World War II Tilburg retained its place as wool capital of the Netherlands
column18: but in the 1960s the industry collapsed and by the 1980s the number of wool mills could be counted on the fingers of one hand. Present-day Tilburg industry consists of a wide variety of enterprises. The main economic sector has become transport and logistics with a variety of industry as a close second.

column1: At the same time as the wool industry collapsed
column2: Cees Becht was the mayor of Tilburg. While he was in office
column3: many buildings were destroyed
column4: including some very precious monuments. The neighbourhood Koningswei (King's Meadows) was demolished and replaced by Koningsplein (King's Square). The old neighbourhood was some kind of slum and had to be replaced by newer development. The newer development
column5: however
column6: wasn't as successful as was expected
column7: and the square feels abandoned most of the year.

column1: Considered even worse was the demolition of the old city hall. This classicistic-styled building was a national-registered monument
column2: but even that didn't stop Becht's plans to demolish it to build the nine-storey
column3: modern-day
column4: black complex. A part of the empty area was used to build the system of the inner Cityring.

column1: Another building that was demolished was the old railway station
column2: which was replaced due to Hoogspoor (literally: high rails)
column3: a project bringing the railway on viaducts to reduce traffic congestion in the years around 1960. The century-old station building was replaced by the modern one.

column1: Because of all of this and some more parts of Tilburg
column2: Cees Becht gained the dubious nickname Cees de Sloper (Cees the demolisher).
many locations
column3: formerly occupied by wool factories had been filled with small-scale housing projects. This mostly happened when Henk Letschert was mayor of Tilburg.

column2: one of the important squares
column3: had its own lime tree until 27 April 1994
column4: being chopped for a bicycle parking basement. The felling led to many protests
column5: because the tree was still healthy. After the Pieter Vreedeplein reconstruction
column6: plans were made to plant a descendant of the original lime tree. Three were placed
column7: only one of them survived. The last living tree was moved to another location again
column8: but died shortly after. As of 23 November 2011
column9: no more descendants have been placed. The current one is just another lime tree.

column1: In the 1990s Tilburg developed a modern skyline. Because of new policy three buildings were built
column2: which are considered skyscrapers in the Netherlands. These are the Interpolis headquarters
column3: the Westpoint Tower and StadsHeer. The Westpoint Tower has an altitude of 143.1 metres (469.5 feet) and was the tallest residential tower in The Netherlands until the Montevideo in Rotterdam surpassed it. The 'StadsHeer' is the third one and is part of the 'Haestrechtkwartier' (Haestrecht quarter). The residential tower is nicknamed De Vogelkooikes (The Bird Cages) for its cubic balconies taped onto the building.

column1: King William II (1792–1849) was fond of Tilburg. "Here I can breathe freely and I feel happy"
column2: he once said about the town. King William II always supported Tilburg—he provided money to improve the sheep breeding
column3: built new farms and founded a cavalry barracks on St. Joseph Street
column4: now a monumental building of the City Archives. Although the King was always made welcome by the manufacturers he had befriended
column5: he needed his own residence in Tilburg
column6: and commissioned the construction of a palace
column7: which would function as his country residence. Construction started in 1847 and was completed just days before William II died
column8: in 1849. It is now part of Tilburg City Hall. In 1987 an obelisk was erected nearby
column9: in memory of King William II. It replaced the old "needle" dating from 1874
column10: which was removed from the street in 1968. After its restoration
column11: William II's statue has got a place again in the heart of the city
column12: where he felt happy among its inhabitants. The local football club Willem II Tilburg was named after the king.

Tilburg experiences an oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification Cfb) similar to almost all of the Netherlands. The most notable fact about Western Brabant is that there are more thunderstorms than anywhere else in the Netherlands
column2: up to 31 days a year.

column1: The economy was concentrated on wool industry for centuries
column2: however
column3: since the 1960s
column4: Tilburg has made more progress in having different kinds of industries
column5: supported by the government to save the city from poverty after the decline of wool industry. Chemical company IFF has a factory in Tilburg. In the 1980s
column6: the Japanese company Fujifilm came to Tilburg. Insurance companies like Interpolis and CZ are headquartered in Tilburg
column7: as well. Iris Ohyama has its European offices in Tilburg. Since a couple of years
column8: the electric car-producing company Tesla has built their main factory for assembly and distribution in Europe in the industrial area of Vossenberg north of the suburb "De Reeshof" in Tilburg.

column1: Tilburg has a high concentration of transportation/distribution industries
column2: specializing in value added logistics and services
column3: due to being the geographical center of the Benelux countries and being located on the transport corridor between Antwerp / Rotterdam and the Ruhr area. The 'Waalwijk-Tilburg' region has been in the logistics hotspots top 3 within the Netherlands for years now and finished 3rd in 2017.

column1: Higher education is of significant importance
column2: with Tilburg University attracting scholars from all over the world. It has a student population of about 13
column3: 000 students
column4: about 8 per cent of whom are international students. With well-facilitated Library
column5: museums and city center with many pubs and cafes
column6: This percentage has steadily increased over the past years. TiU offers both Dutch-taught and English-taught programmes. Tilburg is one of the best cities for exchange students to have great experience in the Netherlands. It is a perfect city for students to work
column7: mingle
column8: get to know each other and make friends.The institution has gained a reputation in both research and education. In the field of economics
column9: the Faculty of Economics and Business Administration ranked No. 1 in Europe for the second consecutive time in 2007 according to the Journal of the European Economic Association with regard to publications in top journals.

column1: In 2007 the Executive MBA program at the university's TiasNimbas Business School ranked # 11 in the world according to the Financial Times. In the field of law
column2: Tilburg University was ranked No. 1 in the Netherlands for the last three years according to Elsevier magazine.

column1: Tilburg is a pilot city of the Council of Europe and the EU Intercultural cities programme.
Schrobbelèr is a local liqueur. It has an alcoholic percentage of 21.5%
column2: slightly lower than most bitters and has a relatively sweet flavour. The drink is sold in a stone jar and is drunk cold from own glass
column3: a high and tiny chalice glass
column4: larger than a Jägermeister glass.

column1: The drink originated in 1973 when Tilburgian entrepreneur Jan Wassing started experimenting with a drink with lower alcoholic percentage that was appropriate for his stomach. The result was successful. The drink is distilled now at Loven industrial area in Tilburg by the Eindhoven company Schrobbeler Ltd
column2: without the è on the last vowel. The drink is especially consumed at Carnival. The name is derived from the profession of 'Schrobbelaar'
column3: in the textile industry in Tilburg. The profession was unskilled and had a low wage.

column1: Another known drink from Tilburg is Peerke's Nat
column2: which has a higher alcoholic percentage than Schrobbelèr (25%) and was introduced at the beatification of Peter Donders (locally named Peerke). The drink is sold in bottles of 70 centiliters.

column1: The Koningshoeven Brewery brews trappist beer. It was founded in 1884 at Koningshoeven Abbey.
